_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Commitment-Safety Approach

Green Bay Dressed Beef, LLC considers their employees to be their most valuable resource, their health and safety is our greatest responsibility.  As our most valuable asset, we place top priority in the informing, educating, protecting and preserving our employees as valuable members of the company.

The company's primary focus is to prevent the occurrence of an unforeseen industrial incident/accident from occuring in the work environment.

Facility Descriptions and Regulated Substance

The operations at the facility consist of the processing of beef and speciality meat cuts.  The facility employs approximately 350 employees.  The refrigeration system at the facility comprises our process with the regulated substance being anhydrous ammonia (NH3).  This is a self contained system which provides the refrigeration for the facility.

Ammonia Refrigeration System Description

The ammonia refrigeration system is a single stage, closed loop system that is used to provide cooling for the process rooms, temperature control, water chilling and temper water for sanitation.  A minimal amount of freezer storage is maintained at the facility.  

5-Year Accident History

There have been no anhydrous ammonia related incidents identified for the facility in the previous five years which resulted in significant on-site or off-site consequences.

To accomplish the facility's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established a multi-faceted safety program.  The objectives of the safety program are to achieve maximum effiency and safety performance.

The facility has implemented a prevention program for the accidental release of the NH3 process.  Elements of the program coincide with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM) 29 CFR 1910.119; EPA's Risk Management Program Regulation (RMP), 40 CFR Part 68; State of Wisconsin's Ref Code: Chapter 45, NH3 Refrigeration and LP Gas Inspection Report.  The purpose of the accidental release p

revention and emergency response program is to prevent occurrences and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fire, explosion and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Components of the Accidental Release Prevention Program

The facility's Accidental Release Prevention Program consists of the following elements:

1) Employee Participation
2) Process Safety Information
3) Process Hazard Analysis
4) Operating Procedures
5) Hot Work Program
6) Management of Change
7) Preventative Maintenance
8) Training
9) Contractors
10) Pre-Start Up Safety Review
11) Mechanical Integrity 
12) Incident Investigation
13) Compliance Audits

An Emergency Response Program has been implemented at the facility.  This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to anydrous ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures.  This program has been coordinated with the Fire Department and LEPC.  

The response plan includes such elements as Orgainizational Plan and Responsibilities, Communication Procedures, Action Plans, Emergency First Aid and Medical Treatment Procedure, Evacuation Procedures, Outside Assistance and Response Training.  

Summary of the Worst Case Scenario and Alternative Release Scenarios

Green Bay Dressed Beef, LLC has diligently and procactively developed emergency response procedures to be followed in the unlikely event of a situation involving the release of anhydrous ammonia, which is commonly used in refrigeration systems in the food industry.  

As required by the EPA and to minimize the risk to our employees and surrounding community, the company has developed a hypothetical worst case scenario.  This model involves the release of 28,000 pounds of ammonia due to a leak from the largest high pressure receiver located outside over a 10 minute period (Liquid Spill and Vaporization) inside the facility boundary.
